tokenized_answer: This meeting was a Children, Young People and Education Committee, and it was conducted in a question and answer format regarding the inquiry into the status of the Welsh baccalaureate qualification.
They had discussions on whether employers understood the meaning of the Welsh bac and how to actually improve the employer's understanding of the Welsh bac.
Then they gave some answers regarding how well the Welsh bac helped to prepare learners for employment.

In addition, they had discussions on whether there was a difference in how the Welsh bac was valued by learners at the different levels that it was studied, and to what extent that universities understood the value of the Welsh bac.
They also talked about how comparable the Welsh bac was to other qualifications.
Then they discussed the idea of universal adoption.
Last but not least, they shared some opinions on the necessity of introducing a specialist teacher-training qualification.

evidence.speaker: Lynne Neagle AM
evidence.content: Welcome to the Children, Young People and Education Committee.

evidence.speaker: Lynne Neagle AM
evidence.content: Item 2, then, is a further evidence session, number four, on our inquiry into the status of the Welsh baccalaureate qualification.

evidence.speaker: Lynne Neagle AM
evidence.content: If it's okay with you, we'll go straight into questions, and the first ones are from Siân Gwenllian.

evidence.speaker: Dafydd Evans
evidence.content: To answer the specific question, no, I don't think that employers have a clear understanding of what the Welsh bac means or what it includes.

evidence.speaker: Dr Rachel Bowen
evidence.content: But we know that most employers in Wales are small or microbusinesses.

evidence.speaker: Dr Rachel Bowen
evidence.content: And that means it's quite a challenge to understand what is the Welsh bac, what does it offer.

evidence.speaker: Sian Gwenllian AM
evidence.content: What are we going to do, then, to improve employers' understanding of the Welsh bac, and whose work is it to try to persuade employers that it is worth while, if you feel that it is worth while, of course?

evidence.speaker: Dafydd Evans
evidence.content: And I think that rather than it being done by the colleges or by a qualifications board, I think the employers—.

evidence.speaker: Ed Evans
evidence.content: I think there are opportunities to join up employers and schools and education facilities a lot more than we do at the moment.

evidence.speaker: Janet Finch-Saunders AM
evidence.content: What are your views on how well the Welsh bac, at all levels, helps to prepare learners for employment?

evidence.speaker: Kay Martin
evidence.content: The Welsh bac, where it works really well, does help prepare them, I think, for employment, but it's not for everyone, because some people have to do the other things.

evidence.speaker: Kay Martin
evidence.content: It helps prepare some people—the A-level students for university—but does it help my health and social care people become more skilled and employable?

evidence.speaker: Kay Martin
evidence.content: No, it doesn't.

evidence.speaker: Janet Finch-Saunders AM
evidence.content: Is there a difference in how the Welsh bac is valued by learners at the different levels that it is studied?

evidence.speaker: Janet Finch-Saunders AM
evidence.content: ColegauCymru said that learners may have had a negative experience of the Welsh bac in previous study.

evidence.speaker: Dafydd Evans
evidence.content: That's been a new dimension lately, I think, in that, when the Welsh bac first hit FE, we were leading the way—

evidence.speaker: Janet Finch-Saunders AM
evidence.content: A question, then, just to ColegauCymru: to what extent do you believe that universities in the main understand the value of the Welsh bac?

evidence.speaker: Kay Martin
evidence.content: Well, we don't think they do, really, especially the experience we have with some of our learners to go to Russell Group universities.

evidence.speaker: Kay Martin
evidence.content: But I think it is mixed, and it does depend on the admissions tutors and the areas that they're going into in universities.

evidence.speaker: Julie Morgan AM
evidence.content: I think you've already got into this bit of the discussion, but what are your views on how comparable the Welsh bac is to other qualifications?

evidence.speaker: Dafydd Evans
evidence.content: Well, obviously, as we noted, it's become a very rigorous, very large qualification.

evidence.speaker: Dafydd Evans
evidence.content: Actually, it's probably larger than an A-level by now.

evidence.speaker: Lynne Neagle AM
evidence.content: We've got some questions now then, from Suzy, on universal adoption.

evidence.speaker: Suzy Davies AM
evidence.content: Well, I'm wondering if I need to ask them, really, because I think I'm getting a strong sense that you all think that universal adoption is a bad idea at this moment in time.

evidence.speaker: Suzy Davies AM
evidence.content: So, for example, we had an indication from the union representing Welsh-speaking teachers that if the baccalaureate was universally adopted, it would remove an artificial choice, basically, for learners, i.e.

evidence.speaker: Kay Martin
evidence.content: And I think, if you'd asked us a few years ago, we were all heading for universal adoption, but because the Welsh bac has changed into something that isn't 100 per cent what we think it should be, then we've stopped the universal adoption, if you like.

evidence.speaker: Dawn Bowden AM
evidence.content: A lot of this has been covered, actually, but just on those final points there, I'm wondering whether you think that introducing a specialist teacher-training qualification to deliver the Welsh bac would actually help in some way in improving its status and perception and so on.

evidence.speaker: Dawn Bowden AM
evidence.content: What do you think about that?

evidence.speaker: Dafydd Evans
evidence.content: I'm not assured in terms of—yes, training is required regarding the Welsh bac, but where we are seeing it more successfully is where vocational lecturers have actually taken it on board.

evidence.speaker: Dafydd Evans
evidence.content: When we were bringing lecturers from outside—'Welsh bac specialists' in inverted commas—it was not working well.

evidence.speaker: Dafydd Evans
evidence.content: Therefore, no, I think that if it's going to be a success, it's got to be contextualised, and for the vocational lecturers to do that, and we've invested heavily in training those vocational lecturers to understand how to deliver the Welsh bac and get positive outcomes of the Welsh bac—.

specific_query_list.query: What did the group discuss about how much employers understood the meaning of Welsh bac?
tokenized_answer: They all agreed that most employers did not have a clear understanding of what Welsh bac means or what it includes, which was a big problem not only for employers, but also for parents and young people.
Though some small engaged employers did understand it, the vast majority focused more on running the business without a clear understanding.

evidence.speaker: Dafydd Evans
evidence.content: So, I just want to give you that context at the outset.

evidence.speaker: Dafydd Evans
evidence.content: To answer the specific question, no, I don't think that employers have a clear understanding of what the Welsh bac means or what it includes.

evidence.speaker: Sian Gwenllian AM
evidence.content: Which is a big problem.

evidence.speaker: Dafydd Evans
evidence.content: Yes, it's a huge problem, but not only to employers, but also to parents and young people, of course.

evidence.speaker: Dr Rachel Bowen
evidence.content: But we know that most employers in Wales are small or microbusinesses.

evidence.speaker: Dr Rachel Bowen
evidence.content: And while there are lots of small engaged employers who have taken an interest and do understand, the vast majority are more focused on getting on with the day-to-day running of the business.

evidence.speaker: Dr Rachel Bowen
evidence.content: And that means it's quite a challenge to understand what is the Welsh bac, what does it offer.

specific_query_list.query: What did Ed Evans (director and secretary of the Civil Engineering Contractors Association) think about employers' understanding of Welsh bac?
tokenized_answer: Ed Evans thought employers did not understand it, but they would appreciate it if they do.
This was particularly true for his own sector, the civil engineering sector, and particularly contracting sector.

Because pupils usually did not have a very strong academic background in this sector, and Welsh bac gave them the opportunity to not pursue that much of academic, but tested them in terms of the challenges.
Therefore, the growth of the Welsh bac would be valued at least for this sector.

evidence.speaker: Ed Evans
evidence.content: I think it's fair to say employers don't understand it, that's for sure, but I think if they did, they would really appreciate this.

evidence.speaker: Ed Evans
evidence.content: For my sector in particular—the civil engineering sector—and particularly the contracting sector, which depends very much on pupils who have come through from a less academic background, the Welsh bac gives them that ability, I guess, not to pursue so much of an academic focus, but to test them in terms of the challenges, but also, to—.

evidence.speaker: Ed Evans
evidence.content: For my sector in particular—the civil engineering sector—and particularly the contracting sector, which depends very much on pupils who have come through from a less academic background, the Welsh bac gives them that ability, I guess, not to pursue so much of an academic focus, but to test them in terms of the challenges, but also, to—.

evidence.speaker: Ed Evans
evidence.content: So, perhaps there are differences across the sector, but I think, certainly for my sector, we would really value the growth of the Welsh baccalaureate.

specific_query_list.query: What did they decide on how to improve employers' understanding of the Welsh bac?
tokenized_answer: They proposed that the voice of employers should be a key part of reviewing the qualification.
Instead of colleges or qualifications boards doing this, employers themselves should do this qualification, which accorded to the vision of the Welsh baccalaureate, to improve skills for employment.
They really should join employers and schools and education facilities together more in the future.

evidence.speaker: Dafydd Evans
evidence.content: I think we need to review the qualification, and I think the voice of employers should be a key part of that review, so that employability skills and entrepreneurial skills have more of a role within that qualification.

evidence.speaker: Dafydd Evans
evidence.content: And I think that rather than it being done by the colleges or by a qualifications board, I think the employers—.

evidence.speaker: Dafydd Evans
evidence.content: Because I think that's what the vision was for the Welsh baccalaureate—that it was going to improve skills for employment.

evidence.speaker: Ed Evans
evidence.content: I think there are opportunities to join up employers and schools and education facilities a lot more than we do at the moment.

specific_query_list.query: Summarize the views about how well the Welsh bac helped to prepare learners for employment.
tokenized_answer: One thing needing to be cleared was that Welsh bac was a combination of qualifications, but not just one qualification.
To develop the employability skills was obviously a key part of it, but not all of it.
It obviously worked well to help prepare for employment, but was not for everyone, because some people had to do the other things.
It helped prepare some people, such as the A level students for university, but did not help health and social care people become more skilled and employable.

evidence.speaker: Nick Brazil
evidence.content: The Welsh bac is a combination of qualifications; it's not just one qualification—it's a combination.

evidence.speaker: Nick Brazil
evidence.content: So, to develop the employability skills obviously is a key part, and developing the skills for employment is a key part.

evidence.speaker: Kay Martin
evidence.content: The Welsh bac, where it works really well, does help prepare them, I think, for employment, but it's not for everyone, because some people have to do the other things.

evidence.speaker: Kay Martin
evidence.content: It helps prepare some people—the A-level students for university—but does it help my health and social care people become more skilled and employable?

evidence.speaker: Kay Martin
evidence.content: No, it doesn't.

specific_query_list.query: Summarize Kay Martin (principal of Cardiff and Vale College) opinion on how well the Welsh bac helped to prepare learners for employment.
tokenized_answer: Kay Martin agreed with other people's opinion.
They tried their best to help learners to develop skills and employable people.
Welsh bac worked well for preparing employment for some people, but not for everybody.
Because some people came to school with very few GCSAs, or were lacking literacy or numeracy skills.
Kay Martin thought this needed to be reviewed, to look at how they could actually make skilled and employable people.

evidence.speaker: Sian Gwenllian AM
evidence.content: I'll be asking my questions in Welsh.

evidence.speaker: Sian Gwenllian AM
evidence.content: Kay, is that your experience?

evidence.speaker: Kay Martin
evidence.content: Certainly, it's very similar, and our employers want to make sure they get the right qualification.

evidence.speaker: Kay Martin
evidence.content: If I could just say as well, our job in the college is to develop skills and employable people, and we use every tool in our box to do that.

evidence.speaker: Kay Martin
evidence.content: The Welsh bac, where it works really well, does help prepare them, I think, for employment, but it's not for everyone, because some people have to do the other things.

evidence.speaker: Kay Martin
evidence.content: As you say, they're coming from schools, some of them with very few GCSEs, or they haven't got literacy and numeracy skills, they're being tested and many of them are below level 1 in terms of literacy and numeracy.

evidence.speaker: Kay Martin
evidence.content: So, I think it needs to be reviewed, to look at how we could make skilled and employable people.

specific_query_list.query: Summarize Dafydd Evans' (chair of ColegauCymru) and Nick Brazil's (deputy principal) opinion on how well the Welsh bac helped to prepare for employment?
tokenized_answer: Dafydd Evans though that one of the problems was that there were a number of priorities.
For example, there were a number of students who needed to resit their GCSE.
It was important for everybody to get a C grade in those core subjects, but that would take some time from them teaching young people.
Therefore, there were fewer and fewer doing level 1 and 2 in the baccalaureate because they were resitting their GCSEs.
Nick Brazil added that Welsh bac was a combination of qualifications, and developing the employment was one of the key parts, but not all of it.

evidence.speaker: Dafydd Evans
evidence.content: I think that one of the problems is that there are a number of priorities.

evidence.speaker: Dafydd Evans
evidence.content: And one of the problems that we have is that we have a number of children coming in to the colleges, and they need to resit their GCSEs—in maths, English and Welsh.

evidence.speaker: Dafydd Evans
evidence.content: It's a valid priority for the Welsh Government for everyone to get a C grade in the core subjects.

evidence.speaker: Dafydd Evans
evidence.content: But that eats into the time that we have to teach young people.

evidence.speaker: Dafydd Evans
evidence.content: So, at levels 1 and 2, there are fewer and fewer doing 1 and 2 in the baccalaureate because they're resitting their GCSEs, and there is much more use of the Welsh bac at level 3, and A-level, and vocational level 3.

evidence.speaker: Nick Brazil
evidence.content: The Welsh bac is a combination of qualifications; it's not just one qualification—it's a combination.

evidence.speaker: Nick Brazil
evidence.content: So, to develop the employability skills obviously is a key part, and developing the skills for employment is a key part.

specific_query_list.query: Summarize the views to what extent they believe that universities understood the value of the Welsh bac.
tokenized_answer: They thought most universities did not understand, based on some experience they had with some of their learners that went to Russell Group universities.
But this depended on the admission tutors and the areas that they were going.
Some areas valued it more, but some others did not.

evidence.speaker: Kay Martin
evidence.content: Well, we don't think they do, really, especially the experience we have with some of our learners to go to Russell Group universities.

evidence.speaker: Kay Martin
evidence.content: But I think it is mixed, and it does depend on the admissions tutors and the areas that they're going into in universities.

evidence.speaker: Kay Martin
evidence.content: In some areas, and certainly the local universities around here—University of South Wales, Cardiff Metropolitan University—value it in a great number of subjects, particularly in sport, when our students go to Cardiff Met, and business studies, when our learners go to USW.

evidence.speaker: Kay Martin
evidence.content: It is valued by them and they accept it, but when people go further afield—and we're always trying to push our learners beyond.

evidence.speaker: Kay Martin
evidence.content: But some of the universities are not valuing the Welsh baccalaureate.

specific_query_list.query: What did Nick Brazil (deputy principal) think about to what extent that universities understood the value of the Welsh bac?
tokenized_answer: Nick Brazil proposed an example of the institution himself was in.
They had a long track record of getting learners into top universities.
50 percent of those Russell Group universities did not value Welsh bac for sure.
But there were some offering an option with the Welsh bac, and those said it was on top of three A2 level grades.

evidence.speaker: Kay Martin
evidence.content: A great number of our learners get into Cardiff using the Welsh baccalaureate, but would their admissions tutors prefer four A-levels?

evidence.speaker: Nick Brazil
evidence.content: Could I jump in there?

evidence.speaker: Nick Brazil
evidence.content: I've got to jump in there as, from the institution I'm in, we've had a long track record of getting learners into top universities.

evidence.speaker: Nick Brazil
evidence.content: I've got to jump in there as, from the institution I'm in, we've had a long track record of getting learners into top universities.

evidence.speaker: Nick Brazil
evidence.content: About 20 per cent of our learners go to Russell Group universities, and there is no doubt—in certainly 50 per cent of those, they do not value the Welsh bac.

evidence.speaker: Nick Brazil
evidence.content: But if they do offer an option with the Welsh bac, they say it is on top of three A2-level grades.

specific_query_list.query: What was the situation in north Wales when discussing to what extent that universities understood the value of the Welsh bac?
tokenized_answer: Welsh universities were much more willing to recognize the bac.
Therefore, it was not a huge problem there.
However, students who were looking to go out to universities in England encountered some problems.
But in terms of Bangor and Glyndŵr University, there was no problem.

evidence.speaker: Dafydd Evans
evidence.content: Because of the nature of our catchment area, there is a greater percentage of our students staying in Welsh universities, and, as Kay said, Welsh universities are much more willing to recognise the bac.

evidence.speaker: Dafydd Evans
evidence.content: So, to a certain extent, it is less of a problem.

evidence.speaker: Dafydd Evans
evidence.content: But, naturally, we do have students who are looking to go out to universities in England in the Russell Group, and we're having the same experience there where there are differences between the policy that that university extols and what actually happens on the ground when students have interviews in those universities.

evidence.speaker: Sian Gwenllian AM
evidence.content: But in terms of Bangor and Glyndŵr University, there's no problem there, though.

specific_query_list.query: Summarize their opinions on introducing a specialist teacher-training qualification to deliver the Welsh bac.
tokenized_answer: They thought that a lot of skills and challenges that were done within the Welsh bac were very similar with the vocational qualification.
Therefore, a number of those staff had already got those skills.

Besides, for the vocational lecturers to do that, they had invested heavily in training those vocational lecturers to understand how to deliver the Welsh bac and got positive outcomes of the Welsh bac, which had been an intensive staff development process.

evidence.speaker: Nick Brazil
evidence.content: And I think you've got to bear in mind that the number of the skills and the number of challenges that are done within the Welsh bac are done very similarly within the vocational qualification as well.

evidence.speaker: Nick Brazil
evidence.content: So, a number of those staff have already got those skills and they're undertaking that.

evidence.speaker: Dafydd Evans
evidence.content: Therefore, no, I think that if it's going to be a success, it's got to be contextualised, and for the vocational lecturers to do that, and we've invested heavily in training those vocational lecturers to understand how to deliver the Welsh bac and get positive outcomes of the Welsh bac—.

evidence.speaker: Dafydd Evans
evidence.content: It's been an intensive staff development process.

specific_query_list.query: What did Dafydd Evans (chair of ColegauCymru) think of introducing a specialist teacher training qualification?
tokenized_answer: Dafydd Evans thought that if it were going to be a success, it would be contextualised.
For the vocational lecturers to do that, they had to invest heavily in training those vocational lecturers to understand how to deliver the Welsh bac and get positive outcomes of the Welsh bac.
And this had been an intensive staff development process.

evidence.speaker: Dafydd Evans
evidence.content: Therefore, no, I think that if it's going to be a success, it's got to be contextualised, and for the vocational lecturers to do that, and we've invested heavily in training those vocational lecturers to understand how to deliver the Welsh bac and get positive outcomes of the Welsh bac—.

evidence.speaker: Dafydd Evans
evidence.content: Therefore, no, I think that if it's going to be a success, it's got to be contextualised, and for the vocational lecturers to do that, and we've invested heavily in training those vocational lecturers to understand how to deliver the Welsh bac and get positive outcomes of the Welsh bac—.

evidence.speaker: Dafydd Evans
evidence.content: It's been an intensive staff development process.

specific_query_list.query: What did Nick Brazil (deputy principal) think of introducing a specialist teacher training qualification?
tokenized_answer: Nick Brazil thought the number of the skills and the number of challenges that were done within the Welsh bac were done very similarly within the vocational qualification.
Therefore, a number of those staff had already got those skills and they had undertaken that.

evidence.speaker: Nick Brazil
evidence.content: And I think you've got to bear in mind that the number of the skills and the number of challenges that are done within the Welsh bac are done very similarly within the vocational qualification as well.

evidence.speaker: Nick Brazil
evidence.content: So, a number of those staff have already got those skills and they're undertaking that.
